liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ABC will continue broadcasting state-based versions of the 7pm TV news bulletin on a Sunday. In June, ABC management proposed running a single national bulletin. Managing Director David Anderson says in an email to staff: "After listening to audience feedback, it is clear that there are some members of the Australian public who continue to rely on the local Sunday night state bulletin. As a result, we will not be proceeding with this current proposal."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ABC reverses decision to scrap state-based Sunday 7pm TV news bulletins

props.alt: An empty ABC News television studio, with desk, chair, and overhead lights

children.content: (ABC)
The ABC will continue broadcasting state-based versions of the 7pm TV news bulletin on a Sunday.
In June, ABC management proposed running a single national bulletin.
Managing Director David Anderson says in an email to staff:
"After listening to audience feedback, it is clear that there are some members of the Australian public who continue to rely on the local Sunday night state bulletin.
As a result, we will not be proceeding with this current proposal."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senator Lidia Thorpe has not travelled to parliament this week on doctor's orders, after being involved in a minor car accident late last week. Thorpe is recovering from whiplash and bruising after she was was rear-ended while in a parked car in Melbourne. Her office tells AAP she is "in pain but is alright". Thorpe has previously raised concerns about her safety and has had some formal protection. She is expected to return to parliament next week.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Senator Lidia Thorpe suffers minor injuries in a car crash

props.alt: A woman with dark hair, a black and white dress and green earrings stands in front of the Aboriginal flag

children.content: Senator Lidia Thorpe has minor injuries
(ABC News)
Senator Lidia Thorpe has not travelled to parliament this week on doctor's orders, after being involved in a minor car accident late last week.
Thorpe is recovering from whiplash and bruising after
she was was rear-ended while in a parked car
in Melbourne.
Her office tells AAP she is "in pain but is alright".
Thorpe has previously raised concerns about her safety and has had some formal protection.
She is expected to return to parliament next week.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A French military transport plane carrying 262 Europeans has arrived in Paris, in the first evacuation flight since mutinous soldiers ousted Niger's democratically elected president and shut its borders. France, Italy and Spain have all announced evacuations from Niger for their citizens and other European nationals, concerned that they risked becoming trapped by the coup. The Associated Press says about 600 French nationals want to leave, along with 400 people of other nationalities from Belgians to Danish, according to officials. The first flight carried mostly French nationals, and officials hope to finish the evacuation flights by today. With Niger's air space closed, France coordinated the evacuations with the regime that ousted the nation's leader, but without withdrawing its support for democratically elected President Mohamed Bazoum, diplomatic officials say. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Europeans begin evacuating from Niger, amid a military coup

featuredLink.title: Evacuations begin in Niger as neighbouring countries warn of war

children.content: Evacuees arrive at Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris
(Reuters : Stephanie Lecocq)

262 Europeans

France, Italy and Spain have all announced evacuations from Niger for their citizens and other European nationals, concerned that they risked becoming trapped
by the coup.
The Associated Press says about
600 French nationals
want to leave, along with
400 people of other nationalities
from Belgians to Danish, according to officials.

children.content: (AP: Sam Mednick)
The first flight carried mostly French nationals, and officials hope to finish the evacuation flights by today.

With Niger's air space closed, France coordinated the evacuations with the regime that ousted the nation's leader, but without withdrawing its support for democratically elected President Mohamed Bazoum, diplomatic officials say.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: A record 947,300 Australians are working multiple jobs, according to the latest estimates from the Australian Bureau of Statistics. That compares to just over 13 million Australians who only hold one job, meaning that 6.6% of all workers are holding down multiple positions. Before COVID, the proportion of workers doing multiple jobs was fairly steady between 5-6%, but has remained above that level since December 2021. On average, multiple job holders worked longer hours than those with only one position. The average multiple job holder worked 30.9 hours a week in their main job and 9.6 hours in their secondary one, for a total of 40.5 hours — above a standard working week. Single job holders worked 35.5 hours per week on average. Men with multiple jobs worked the longest hours, on average, at 45.3, women with multiple jobs worked an average of 36.4 hours a week in paid employment. Women were more likely to hold multiple jobs (7.7%) than men (5.7%). Those aged 20-24 were most likely to hold more than one job (8.9%), while 7.9% of employed 15-19-year-olds also held more than one job. Only 5.5% of employed people aged 60-64 and 5.2% of those working aged 65 or older worked more than one job. Those working in agriculture, forestry and fishing, administrative and support services, arts and recreation, accommodation and food services, healthcare and social assistance, and education and training had the highest rates of multiple job holding (all above 7%). Those employed by utilities, financial and insurance firms, wholesalers, manufacturers and logistics firms were the least likely to hold multiple jobs (less than 5%).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Record number of Australians working multiple jobs

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian share market has given back yesterday's gains and then some. Investors are worried about data showing the manufacturing industry contracting around the world including in China. The ASX 200 is down 0.8 per cent, although CommSec points out that is just 3 per cent from its record high. Most sectors are in the red with utilities leading the losses after AGL Energy was sold off on a stockbroker downgrade. Real estate firms, financial stocks and miners are also weighing on the market. Top movers on ASX 200: BrainChip: +4% Pro Medicus: +2.6% Domino's Pizza: +2.1% Regis Resources: -4.3% AGL Energy: -4.1% Champion Iron: -3.6%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red at midday

children.content: The Australian share market has given back yesterday's gains and then some.
Investors are worried about data showing the manufacturing industry contracting around the world including in China.
The ASX 200 is down 0.8 per cent, although CommSec points out that is just 3 per cent from its record high.
Most sectors are in the red with utilities leading the losses after AGL Energy was sold off on a stockbroker downgrade.
Real estate firms, financial stocks and miners are also weighing on the market.
Top movers on ASX 200:
BrainChip: +4%
Pro Medicus: +2.6%
Domino's Pizza: +2.1%
Regis Resources: -4.3%
AGL Energy: -4.1%
Champion Iron: -3.6%

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: New Zealand's unemployment rate climbed to a two-year high over the June quarter amid a rise in the number of people looking for work. While the labour market is tight, the jobless rate rose from 3.4 per cent to 3.6 per cent seasonally adjusted with 109,000 people out of work according to Statistics New Zealand. It says the labour force participation rate of 72.4 per cent and the employment rate of 69.8 per cent are the highest on record. The tourism industry drove the increase with employment returning to pre-COVID levels. Wages increased by 4.3 per cent over the year to June. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to leave official interest rates unchanged at 5.5 per cent this month. The country's economy is in recession which was triggered by the central bank's aggressive rate rise campaign. While New Zealand's jobless rate is at a two-year high, Australia's unemployment rate of 3.5 per cent, is near a 50-year low. New Zealand closed its borders from early 2020 to mid-2022 because of COVID-19, which drove down the unemployment rate because temporary migration was restricted. Here's quick guide from CommSec on the unemployment rates in major economies: US: 3.6% UK: 4% Australia: 3.5% New Zealand: 3.6% Canada: 5.4% China: 5.2% Singapore: 1.9% Japan: 2.5% Netherlands: 3.5% Germany: 5.6% We are doing pretty good, even the unemployment rate rises to 4.5 per cent as the RBA predicts.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Zealand unemployment rate at two year high

children.content: New Zealand's unemployment rate climbed to a two-year high over the June quarter amid a rise in the number of people looking for work.
While the labour market is tight, the jobless rate rose from 3.4 per cent to 3.6 per cent seasonally adjusted with 109,000 people out of work according to Statistics New Zealand.

props.alt: Graph showing the NZ jobless rate

children.content: NZ jobless rate
(Statistics New Zealand )
It says the labour force participation rate of 72.4 per cent and the employment rate of 69.8 per cent are the highest on record.
The tourism industry drove the increase with employment returning to pre-COVID levels.
Wages increased by 4.3 per cent over the year to June.
The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to leave official interest rates unchanged at 5.5 per cent this month.
The country's economy is in recession which was triggered by the central bank's aggressive rate rise campaign.
While New Zealand's jobless rate is at a two-year high, Australia's unemployment rate of 3.5 per cent, is near a 50-year low.
New Zealand closed its borders from early 2020 to mid-2022 because of COVID-19, which drove down the unemployment rate because temporary migration was restricted.
Here's quick guide from CommSec on the unemployment rates in major economies:
UK: 4%
Australia: 3.5%
New Zealand: 3.6%
Canada: 5.4%
China: 5.2%
Singapore: 1.9%
Japan: 2.5%
Netherlands: 3.5%
Germany: 5.6%
We are doing pretty good, even the unemployment rate rises to 4.5 per cent as the RBA predicts.
